titleStmt.title:
An Answer to Hamilton's Bawn, or
A short Character of Doctr 08. Swift

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

encodingDesc.p: tochk items resolved in situ JW 14JA05; ed. JW 6AP17

lg.l: Is Swift's Ingratitude proclaim'd again?
Must his best Freinds still feel his sharpest Pen?
Shall he expose 'em to the World in Rhyme,
And no one dare to tell him of his Crime?
Galls-Town is long in wish'd Oblivion lost;
The only Vict'ry Death o'er him can boast.
\In·over·O!\ Dust deserv'd, that odious Iournal lies;
O! had it ne'er appear'd to Mortal Eyes,
Unsully'd then had stood the Draper's Name,
And unborn Tongues proclaim'd the Patriot's Fame;
Now fresh, alas! the black Remembrance lives,
Galls-Town again in Market-Hill revives.
A secret Poison lurks within his Breast,
He censures most, where most he is caress'd;
A dang'rous Guest, a false and treach'rous Freind,
Few dare provoke him, and as few commend.
Whate'er our Dean, or fancies, sees, or hears,
In Rhyme and Billingsgate Lampoon appears:
When e'er that's done, he then has gain'd his Ends;
Won't lose one Iest, to keep the best of Freinds;
Freinds, Foes or Kindred are alike to him,
They all partake of his illnatur'd Whim;
The Secrets of each Family display'd;
Sure! six Month's Visits, thus are well repaid?
How mean, alass! the Patriot now appears?
How chang'd a Character, the Draper bears?
Since nor the Laws of hospitable Iove,
Nor strictest tyes of Gratitude or Love,
Nor Truth itself, nor Freindships sacred Bands,
Can stop from Satyr, his envenom'd hand,
May I be one of those he deigns to hate;
Nor meet with Rochfort's, or Sir Arthur's Fate.
Fore-warn'd, fore-arm'd, ev'n heathen Bards coud sing;
Who warms a Viper, must expect a Sting;
In days of Yore, the Pow'r of Witch-craft's known
To 'clipse the Sun, and hide the lab'ring Moon;
Swifts Sin is more than Witch-craft── has done more,
Darkn'd those Lights admiring Worlds adore:
Scorch'd by it's Breath, the verdent Laurels fade,
And all the haughty Honours of the Head;
Ungratefull Acts can such dishonours raise,
And stop all Mouths, that sing the Draper's Praise;
Not all the saucy Scriblers of the Age,
With all their little Wit, their litle Rage,
Coud ever sully one Immortal Line;
His Works shone brighter,── still the more divine;
None but himself coud e'er himself defame,
And none but Swift, eclipse the Drapers Name.
